title: 108_s759
content: The Act titled "Residential, Farm, Ranch, and Small Business Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" or "Small Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" introduces a credit for residential small wind energy systems under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures made by individuals. The credit is limited to $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requires safety certifications. Any excess credit can be carried forward to the next taxable year. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures allows a 30% credit for installation on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence. The property must be a qualifying wind turbine with a 5-year warranty. Any excess credit can be carried forward to the next taxable year. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures allows a 30% credit for installation on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence. A qualifying wind turbine must have a 5-year warranty and a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less. Labor costs for onsite preparation, assembly, or original installation are also eligible for the credit. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures allows a 30% credit for installation on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence. Labor costs for onsite preparation, assembly, or original installation of qualified wind energy property are eligible for the credit. Expenditures for swimming pools or other energy storage mediums with functions other than storage are not eligible for the credit. Special rules apply for joint occupancy dwelling units. Special rules apply for joint occupancy dwelling units, where the credit allowable for expenditures made by individuals is determined by treating them as one taxpayer for the taxable year. Each individual is allowed a credit based on the ratio of their expenditures to the total amount determined for the dwelling unit. In the case of individuals making expenditures, a credit is given based on the ratio of their expenses to the total amount spent by all individuals. Tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations are treated as having made their share of expenditures. For individuals in condominium management associations, a credit is available based on their association membership. Individuals in condominium management associations are treated as having made their proportionate share of any expenditures of the association. The text discusses the allocation of expenditures for qualified wind energy property used for nonbusiness purposes. Expenditures are considered made when the property is installed and begins generating energy. Expenditures for qualified wind energy property are considered made when the property is installed and begins generating energy. Property financed by subsidized energy financing is not included in the calculation of expenditures for a dwelling unit. Basis adjustments are made if a credit is allowed for any expenditure related to qualified wind energy property. The credit for qualified wind energy property excludes expenditures from subsidized energy financing. Basis adjustments are made if a credit is allowed, and the section does not apply to property installed after December 31, 2008. The credit allowed for the taxable year is limited by the regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55. The credit allowed for the taxable year is limited by the regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code to conform with the new limitations. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to include new limitations on tax credits, such as inserting subsections and amending sections to include references to section 25C. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including adding references to section 25C in different subsections and amending existing sections to include new limitations on tax credits. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include adding references to section 25C in different subsections and inserting new limitations on tax credits. The amendments made by this section apply to residential wind energy property expenditures after December 31, 2002, for taxable years ending after that date. Subsection (b) amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. A credit is also provided for business installation of small wind energy property. The amendments define qualified wind energy property as a qualifying wind turbine installed on a farm, ranch, or eligible small business in the US before January 1, 2009. The qualified wind energy property must be installed on a farm, ranch, or eligible small business in the US, owned and used by the taxpayer, with the original use commencing with the taxpayer, and carrying at least a 5-year limited warranty. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. A qualifying wind turbine must have a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less and meet performance standards. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. A wind turbine of 75 kilowatts or less must meet performance standards and safety certifications to be eligible for the credit. The energy percentage for qualified wind energy property is 30%, while for other energy property, it is 10%. Section 29(b)(3)(A)(i)(III) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended. These amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2003.
